text: The quantity of motion of a body is its
explanation:
Momentum is a physical quantity that describes the motion of an object. It is defined as the product of an object's mass and its velocity.
Unlike acceleration, displacement, and velocity, which describe different aspects of motion, momentum specifically quantifies the motion of a body.

text: An image formed on a screen is always?
explanation: A real image is defined asAn image that is formed when the light rays from an object converge and meet each other and can be projected onto a screen.Real images are alwaysinverted, Real images can be projected onto pieces of paper or screens. An example of a real image is the image formed on a cinema screen.A virtual image is defined asAn image that is formed when the light rays from an object do not meet but appear to meet behind the lens and cannot be projected onto a screen.Virtual images are alwaysupright, Virtual imagescannotbe projected onto a piece of paper or a screen. An example of a virtual image is a person's reflection in a mirror.

text: Two identical cups containing the same volume of water at 45°C and 5°C, are left in a room at 25°C. Which of the following graphs correctly illustrates the variation of temperature with time?
explanation: The cup containing water at 45∘C loses heat to the room since temperature of the room is lower than its temperature, hence its temperature reduces gradually, the cup containing water at 5∘C gains heat from the room since its temperature is lower than that of the room. hence, its temperature increases gradually, the lines are curved because as the temperature of the water changes the temperature difference between the water and surroundings also changes

text:
A ray of light traveling from glass into ethyl alcohol is incident at the boundary at an angle of incidence 30\(^o\). Calculate the angle of refraction.
[Refractive index of glass =1.5; refractive index of ethyl alcohol = 1.36]
explanation:
The angle of incidence l = 30ºThe angle of refraction , r =?The refractive index of glass ng = 1.5The refractive index of ethyl alcohol, ne = 1.36from snell's law :
\(\frac{n_e}{n_g} = \frac{sini}{sinr}\)
\(\frac{1.36}{1.5} = \frac{sin30º}{sinr}\)
1.36sinr = 1.5 x sin30º
sinr =  \(\frac{1.5 \times sin30º}{1.36}\)
sinr = 0.5515
r = \(sin^{-1}\)(0.5515)
r = 33.5º

text: The length of an iron bar is 100cm at 20°C. At what temperature will its length increase by 0.01%? [Linear expansivity of iron = 1.2 x 10\(^{-5}\)°C]
explanation:
GIVEN DATA:
where ΔL is the increase in length = 0.01L1 is the initial length  = 100
T1 = 20
T2 = ?α is the linear expansivity of iron = 1.2 x 10\(^{-5}\)°C
FormulaΔL = L1αΔT
ΔT = \(\frac{ΔL}{L1α}\)
ΔT is the change in temperature  = T2 - T1
T2 = \(\frac{ΔL}{L1α}\) + T1
T2 = \(\frac{0.01}{100 \times 1.2 x 10^{-5}}\) + 20
T2 = 8.3 + 20
T2 = 28.3

text: A parallel plate capacitor is charged and the charging battery is subsequently disconnected. lf the plates of the capacitor are moved farther apart by means of insulating handles, the

options.C: charge on the capacitor would increase
options.D: charge on the capacitor would decrease

explanation: As the distance between the plates increases, the ability of the capacitor to store charge (capacitance) decreases. Since the battery is disconnected, the charge remains constant, but the voltage across the plates increases.

text: The velocity of sound in air at 15°C is 340ms\(^{-1}\). Calculate the velocity at 47\(^o\)C
explanation:
Given the velocity of sound at \( 15^\circ C \):
\(v_0 = 340 \, \text{m/s}\)
The absolute temperatures are:
\(T_0 = 15 + 273.15 = 288.15 \, \text{K}\)
\(T = 47 + 273.15 = 320.15 \, \text{K}\)
We use the formula for the velocity of sound:
\(v = v_0 \sqrt{\frac{T}{T_0}}\)
Substituting the known values:
\(v = 340 \times \sqrt{\frac{320.15}{288.15}}\)
Calculating the ratio of temperatures:
\(\frac{320.15}{288.15} \approx 1.111\)
Taking the square root:
\(\sqrt{1.111} \approx 1.054\)
Finally, calculating the new velocity:
\(v \approx 340 \, \text{m/s} \times 1.054 \approx 358.6 \, \text{m/s}\)
The velocity of sound in air at \( 47^\circ C \) is approximately:
\(v \approx 358.6 \, \text{m/s}\)

text: The diagram illustrates a ball of mass m sliding down a plank inclined at an angle of 0 to the horizontal. The kinetic friction between the ball and the plank is F, and the acceleration of free fall is g. The normal force on the ball is?
explanation: The normal reaction/force on a body on a horizontal surface is R = mg; but that on a body on an inclined surface is R = mgCosθ.

text: The diagram above illustrates a ball of mass m sliding down a plank inclined at an angle of 0 to the horizontal. The kinetic friction between the ball and the plank is F and the acceleration of free fall is g. The net force on the ball along the plank is?
explanation:
The force causing the ball to roll down the inclined plane is greater than the one pulling it up, resolving the force in its component we have \(mgsin\theta\)
therefore the Net Force acting on the ball = \(mgsin\theta\) - F

text: What factors determine the frequency of a note emitted by a vibrating string?

options.A: Amplitude of vibration, force constant of string and length of string
options.B: Amplitude of vibration, force constant of string, and tension in string
options.C: Mass per unit length of string, tension in string and length of string
options.D: Force constant of string, tension in string, and length of string.

explanation:
The fundamental frequency of vibrations of a string is inversely proportional to the square root of mass per unit length (linear density),
if the tension and vibrating length of the string are constant.

The temperature of an object is raised by 120°C. The resulting increase in its absolute temperature is
explanation:
Object temperature = 120ºC
So, 0ºC  + 273 = K
K = 120  + 273 = 393K
Increase in temperature = 0ºC to 120ºC
⇒ 273K to 393K = ( 393 - 273) = 120K
NOTE: The change in temperature in Kelvin is equal to the change in temperature in Celsius: ΔT(K) = ΔT(°C)

Motion of charged particles in Magnetic field

text: The sketched graph above illustrates the heating curve of a 0.02kg of water. Determine the approximate value of the specific latent heat of vapourization of water
explanation:
specific latent heat of vapourization is the amount of heat energy needed to change 1kg of liquid to vapour without a temperature change. The heat absorbed by the liquid at the beginning of vapourization is \(8 \times 10^3\)J and heat absorbed after the change of stage is \(53 \times 10^3\)J. therefore, the total heat energy needed to change the liquid completely to vapour is Q = \(53 \times 10^3 - 8 \times 10^3 J = 45 \times10^3\)JRecall, Q = mLWhere, L = specific latent heat of vapourization
Q = mL
L = \(\frac{ Q}{m}\) = \(\frac{ 45 \times 10^3}{0.02}\)
L = \(2.25 \times10^6JKg^{-1}\)

text: In an electric circuit, an inductor of inductance 0.5 H and resistance 50\(\Omega\) is connected to an alternating current source of frequency 60 Hz. Calculate the impedance of the circuit.
explanation:
The impedance of a R-L circuit is given by:
Z = √(R\(^2\) + XL\(^2\)) ----------- eqn(1)
where Z is the impedance,
R is the resistance, and
XL is the inductive reactance
XL = 2πfL ------------ eqn(2)
where f is the frequency
From eqn(2),
XL = 2 * π * 60 * 0.5
= 60π
Also, from eqn(1),
Z = √(50\(^2\) + (60π)\(^2\))
Z = 195.0Ω

text: Water waves have a wavelength of 3.6cm and speed of 18cms\(^{-1 }\) in deep water. If the waves enter shallow water with wavelength of 2.0cm, calculate the speed of the waves in the shallow water.
explanation:
Velocity = frequency x wavelength
v = 18cm/s, wavelength = 3.6cm, then F = 5hertz
therefore, the speed of the wave in the shallow water = 5 x 2 = 10cm/s
NOTE; as a general rule, the frequency of a wave remains constant while speed and wavelength change as it travels from one medium to another.

text: An electron of mass 9.1x 10\(^{-31}\) kg is travelling at a speed of 2.0 x 10\(^6\)ms\(^{-1}\). Calculate the associate wavelength of the electron. [h = 6.6. x 10\(^{-34}\) Js]
explanation:
Using de Broglie wavelength formula:  \(\lambda\) = \(\frac{h}{p}\)
P = momentum = mass x velocity = 9.1x 10\(^{-31}\) x 2.0 x 10\(^6\) = 1.82 × 10\(^{ −24}\) kg m/s
\(\lambda\) = \(\frac{6.6. \times 10^{-34}}{1.82 \times 10^{ −24}}\) = 3.63 x 10\(^{-10}\) m

text: Which of the following statement about viscosity is not true? it

options.A: depends on areas of the surfaces in contact
options.C: is independent of the relative velocity of the layers
options.D: depends on the tangential force between the layers

explanation:
Is independent of the relative velocity of the layers is not true because:
Viscosity is dependent on the relative velocity of the layers in a fluid; it describes how the fluid flows when layers move relative to each other.
Viscosity depends on the area of the surface in contactViscosity is independent of normal reactionViscosity depends on the relative velocity between layers
